q01.title: Timeline Snapshot
q01.prompt: Before we go deep, give a simple snapshot so we interpret everything in context.

fields.label: How long have you known each other total
How long have you been intentionally dating/seeing each other?
About how often do you see each other right now?

examples: 2 (years); 6 (months); weekly. notes: We were friends first, then shifted into dating. We do one longer date and one shorter hangout most weeks.
6 (weeks); 3 (weeks); multiple times/week. notes: New relationship energy is high, so we are moving fast and trying to sanity-check it.
9 (months); 2 (months); varies. notes: Work travel and family schedules make it inconsistent, which affects how secure the connection feels.

q02.title: The Notification Reaction
q02.prompt: When their name pops up on your phone, your first micro-reaction is usually:
examples: Warmth or smile (e.g., I instinctively feel fondness or excitement, even if I'm busy. Their message feels like a good thing, not a task).
Calm and steady (e.g., it feels normal and safe. I do not overthink it, I just respond when I can).
Anxious or tight (e.g., my stomach drops because I do not know what mood they are in, or I worry I did something wrong).
Dread or avoidance (e.g., I see it and want to ignore it because it usually leads to tension, pressure, or emotional labor).
It depends lately (e.g., some days it is warmth, other days it is tightness. The variability itself is the data).

q03.title: Post-Date Energy
q03.prompt: After a longer stretch together (a date, an evening, or a day), your energy is usually:
examples: recharged (e.g., I leave feeling clearer and more regulated. I am more productive and more myself afterward).
steady and neutral (e.g., it was fine and pleasant. No big spike up or down, just stable).
tired but happy (e.g., it was connecting, but I used a lot of social energy. I want quiet time, not distance).
tired and stressed (e.g., I feel like I performed, managed emotions, or walked on eggshells. I need recovery because it cost me).
varies a lot (e.g., good when things are easy, draining when logistics or conflict appears, which tells me what triggers the strain).

q04.title: Masking / Filtering
q04.prompt: When you're with them for a long stretch, how much do you feel you have to perform or filter yourself?

options.label: moderate filtering, I'm careful about what I say/do
heavy masking, I feel like I have to be on to be liked

examples: none, I'm fully myself (e.g., I can be tired, awkward, or honest about my limits and it does not threaten the connection).
light filtering, mostly myself (e.g., I soften some opinions early on, but I am not afraid to be real and I do not feel punished for it).
moderate filtering, I'm careful about what I say/do (e.g., I am actively monitoring my tone, words, or topics to avoid reactions).
heavy masking, I feel like I have to be on to be liked (e.g., I feel like I am auditioning. If I relax, I fear they will lose interest).
not sure yet (e.g., we have not spent enough long stretches together to know what my nervous system does).

q05.title: What's Feeling Good
q05.prompt: Let's start with what's working. This matters.

fields.label: 3 things that feel genuinely good or healthy right now
One moment you felt especially safe, cared for, or understood

examples: 1) we keep our plans and follow through 2) we can talk about hard topics without it turning into a fight 3) we laugh easily and recover quickly from small misunderstandings. One moment you felt especially safe, cared for, or understood: When I admitted I was anxious and they listened, reflected it back, and did not try to fix me.

1) they respect my boundaries without sulking 2) we are affectionate in a way that feels mutual, not pressured 3) I feel included in their real life, not hidden. One moment you felt especially safe, cared for, or understood: They checked on me after a family situation and asked what support actually helps, instead of assuming.

1) consistent communication 2) shared values in daily choices 3) conflict stays respectful. One moment you felt especially safe, cared for, or understood: After a tense moment, they owned their part, apologized clearly, and we repaired the same day.

q06.title: Pace Comfort
q06.prompt: Right now, the pace of the relationship feels:

options.label: a little fast for my nervous system

examples: Comfortably paced (e.g., closeness is increasing naturally and I do not feel rushed or stalled. My nervous system stays calm).
A little fast for my nervous system (e.g., the connection is good, but I notice myself getting tight, overwhelmed, or pressured to keep up).
Too fast (e.g., big commitment talk or expectations are happening before trust and patterns have had time to prove themselves).
A little slow (e.g., I am mostly okay, but I want clearer movement toward exclusivity, integration, or intentional planning).
It varies (e.g., when we are together it feels fast, when we are apart it feels slow. The inconsistency is the problem, not the pace itself).

q07.title: Current Status (Reality vs Label)
q07.prompt: If a kind stranger asked What are you two?, the most accurate answer is:

options.label: Exploring / getting to know each other
Dating intentionally, still open to others
Functionally exclusive (not seeing others), but undefined

examples: Exploring / getting to know each other (e.g., we enjoy each other but nothing is promised. If one of us dated someone else, it would be disappointing but not a betrayal).
Dating intentionally, still open to others (e.g., we are genuinely evaluating compatibility, but we have not closed the door to meeting others).
Functionally exclusive (not seeing others), but undefined (e.g., we act exclusive and would be hurt if the other dated, but we have not explicitly agreed).
Exclusive and defined (boyfriend/girlfriend/partner) (e.g., we have stated what we are, what exclusivity means, and what standards we expect).
It's complicated (e.g., we do couple things, but there are mixed signals, unclear boundaries, or mismatched expectations that keep it foggy).

q08.title: What DTR Means to Me
q08.prompt: If you define the relationship, what does that specifically mean to you? Select all that fit.

options.label: Future intent becomes more explicit (where this is going)

examples: Exclusivity (no dating others) + deleting/pausing dating apps. notes: I want clean emotional safety, not wondering who else is in the picture.
A clear label (boyfriend/girlfriend/partner) + public clarity (friends/social media). notes: I do not want ambiguity in social settings or to feel hidden.
Increased consistency (time, communication, follow-through) + clearer expectations and boundaries. notes: DTR should make day-to-day more stable, not just add a title.

Deeper emotional responsibility (repair matters more) + future intent becomes more explicit (where this is going). notes: I want us to treat conflict seriously and know we are building toward something, not drifting.

q09.title: Exclusivity Definition (Operational)
q09.prompt: People mean different things by exclusive. What would exclusivity mean to you right now?

fields.label: Which are part of exclusivity for you?

options.label: transparency about close friendships that could create confusion
agreement on emotional boundaries (what counts as betrayal)

examples: No dating other people + deleting/pausing dating apps. notes: If we are exclusive, I want it to be clean and obvious, not vague.
No flirting/keeping doors open + agreement on emotional boundaries (what counts as betrayal). notes: The line for me is entertaining romantic attention, not just having friends.
Transparency about close friendships that could create confusion + ex-boundaries. notes: I do not need control, I need clarity so I do not have to guess.
Agreement on physical boundaries + other (write in). If other, describe: We do not do private one-on-one hangouts with exes. notes: This is about preventing predictable confusion, not policing.

q10.title: Why This Check-In Now
q10.prompt: What is driving the urge to define things right now? Select any that fit, then rank the ones that matter most.

options.label: desire: I genuinely want to move forward
safety: I need clarity to feel steady
fear: I'm afraid of losing them or being replaced
logic: enough time has passed for a decision point
discomfort: the ambiguity is starting to hurt
pressure: external pressure (friends, family, age, etc.)
spiritual: I feel spiritual clarity or prompting

examples: Desire: I genuinely want to move forward > logic: enough time has passed for a decision point > safety: I need clarity to feel steady. notes: I like who we are together, and the only thing missing is a clean agreement.

Discomfort: the ambiguity is starting to hurt > safety: I need clarity to feel steady > desire: I genuinely want to move forward. notes: The uncertainty is costing me peace, even though I still want the relationship.

Fear: I'm afraid of losing them or being replaced > pressure: external pressure (friends, family, age, etc.) > other (write in). If other, describe: I feel behind in life. notes: I want to separate real desire from panic before we label anything.

Spiritual: I feel spiritual clarity or prompting > desire: I genuinely want to move forward > logic: enough time has passed for a decision point. notes: I feel unusually clear and calm, not rushed or desperate.

q11.title: What Should Change After Labeling
q11.prompt: If you define the relationship, what do you believe should change (if anything)?

fields.label: Select any that you expect to change

options.label: nothing major should change, just clarity

examples: Communication consistency + time together. notes: I do not need constant texting, but I do want a predictable rhythm and planned time so I am not guessing.
Clarity about exclusivity + physical/sexual boundaries. notes: Labeling should include explicit agreements so neither of us is assuming and then feeling betrayed.
Emotional responsibility and follow-through + repair matters more. notes: If we label this, I want conflict to be handled with ownership and repair, not avoidance.
Nothing major should change, just clarity. notes: We already behave like partners. The title is about alignment and public clarity, not changing behavior.

q12.title: Expectations You're Carrying
q12.prompt: Name the expectations you already have, even if you haven't said them out loud.

fields.label: Which of these feel fair vs possibly unrealistic?

examples: 1) We communicate daily in a simple way 2) We do not keep dating doors open 3) We repair conflict within 24 hours. Fair vs possibly unrealistic: The repair expectation is fair, but 24 hours might be unrealistic during work travel. A better standard is: we name it and schedule repair.

1) If we are exclusive, ex contact has clear boundaries 2) I meet key friends/family within a reasonable timeline. Fair vs possibly unrealistic: Meeting family fast might be unrealistic if family is complicated. The fair core is: I do not want to feel hidden.

1) We plan at least one intentional date per week 2) Follow-through matters (no constant rescheduling) 3) We talk about direction within the next month. Fair vs possibly unrealistic: The direction talk is fair, but I may be over-attaching it to security instead of gathering data.

q13.title: Communication Expectations
q13.prompt: In an ideally healthy defined relationship, communication consistency would look like:

options.label: steady but simple (a basic daily touchpoint)
consistent and connected (regular check-ins, predictable rhythm)

examples: light and flexible, no pressure (e.g., we text when it makes sense, and silence does not mean drama. The relationship is secure enough to breathe).
steady but simple (a basic daily touchpoint) (e.g., one check-in most days plus a quick plan for when we will see each other next).
consistent and connected (regular check-ins, predictable rhythm) (e.g., we have a normal cadence: a brief daily touchpoint and a deeper call or check-in a couple times a week).
highly integrated (frequent contact, shared planning) (e.g., we naturally coordinate schedules, share small life updates throughout the day, and it feels mutual, not monitored).

q14.title: Exclusivity Reality Check
examples: Yes (e.g., we explicitly agreed: no dating others, apps are paused, and we clarified what counts as flirting or betrayal).
No (e.g., we like each other, but we have not made agreements and either of us could still date).
Not sure (e.g., we act exclusive sometimes, but the rules are unclear and I would not be able to call it a clear agreement).
We haven't defined it (e.g., we are basically behaving like a couple, but we have never said the words or clarified boundaries).
It's complicated (e.g., mixed signals, unclear boundaries, or a situation like distance, ex overlap, or timing that makes exclusivity unclear).

q15.title: Exclusivity Safety and Stability
q15.prompt: If exclusivity is involved (or hoped for), how steady does it feel right now?
examples: Very steady. What makes it feel clear: They follow through, communicate consistently, and we have explicit boundaries about others. What makes it feel unclear: Nothing major right now, it feels aligned.

Mostly steady. What makes it feel clear: Their actions show commitment and they include me in plans. What makes it feel unclear: When conflict happens they go quiet, so I start guessing where I stand.
Unclear. What makes it feel clear: We act exclusive when together. What makes it feel unclear: There is no explicit agreement and I notice evasiveness around attention from others.

q16.title: Boundaries and Pace Compatibility
q16.prompt: Right now, do your boundaries and pacing feel compatible?
examples: Aligned; physical pace: aligned; communication pace: aligned; time/availability pace: aligned; notes: We both want to build steadily, we talk at a similar frequency, and our physical boundaries feel mutual.

Slightly mismatched; physical pace: aligned; communication pace: slightly mismatched; time/availability pace: aligned; notes: I am more emotionally invested right now and I want more reassurance than they naturally give, but we can talk about it without pressure.

Mismatched; physical pace: mismatched; communication pace: aligned; time/availability pace: slightly mismatched; notes: The biggest friction is physical pacing and availability. We need explicit boundaries and a realistic schedule so no one feels rejected or pushed.

q17.title: Integration Pace
q17.prompt: The pace of integrating lives (friends, family, routines, church/community visibility if applicable) feels:

options.label: a little fast for my nervous system

examples: healthy and comfortable (e.g., meeting friends and showing up in each other's real life feels natural, not performative or pressured).
a little fast for my nervous system (e.g., I like them, but public visibility or family integration is happening before I feel settled).
too fast (e.g., expectations around family, church/community visibility, or routines feel like a forced escalator).
too slow (e.g., I feel compartmentalized. I am not asking to rush, but I need to know I am not being hidden).

q18.title: Daily Operating Systems
q18.prompt: How do your day-to-day rhythms (sleep, cleanliness, pace, planning vs spontaneity, chaos tolerance) fit?
examples: seamless, very similar (e.g., sleep, cleanliness, planning style, and pace are naturally compatible. Coexisting would feel easy).
different but complementary (e.g., one is spontaneous and one is structured, but we respect it and build a rhythm that uses both strengths).
workable with some coordination (e.g., we need agreements on things like planning ahead, chores, or sleep routines, but it feels solvable).
frequent friction (e.g., I feel stressed by their chaos tolerance or last-minute changes, and it keeps repeating despite conversations).

q19.title: The Pink Flag Check (Chemistry Filter)
q19.prompt: Is there something you're minimizing because the chemistry is strong? You can keep it high-level.

fields.label: Are you ignoring a small-but-real concern?

examples: No; Optional context: The chemistry is strong, but it is not blinding me. We have talked through the main risks.
Yes (conflict behavior): When tension hits, they go cold or disappear. The chemistry makes me excuse it, but it would be a serious long-term problem.
Unsure; If yes/unsure: ex-boundaries; Optional context: There are friendships that feel ambiguous and I am not sure if I am overreacting or noticing a real instability.

q20.title: Emotional Safety
q20.prompt: Do you feel emotionally safe being fully honest with this person?

fields.label: What makes it feel less safe

examples: Yes. What makes it feel safe: They stay kind in hard conversations, do not punish honesty, and they repair quickly. What makes it feel less safe: I still get a little guarded around one topic, but it is shrinking.
Mostly. What makes it feel safe: They listen and validate. What makes it feel less safe: I edit myself when I fear being seen as too intense, needy, or critical.
Sometimes. What makes it feel safe: When they are regulated, they are great. What makes it feel less safe: When stressed, they get defensive or dismissive, so I choose silence.
Not really. What makes it feel safe: Very little. What makes it feel less safe: I fear backlash, judgment, or withdrawal if I am fully honest.

q21.title: Eggshells Check
q21.prompt: Do you feel you have to manage their emotions to keep peace?
examples: No (e.g., I can bring up needs directly and it does not become a mood event. We can handle discomfort without punishment).
Sometimes (e.g., I delay certain topics until the timing feels safe because I do not want an overreaction).
Often (e.g., I pre-edit my words, scan their tone, and choose peace over honesty more than I want to).
Yes, regularly (e.g., I am managing their emotions like a job. The relationship has a peace-keeping tax).

q22.title: Felt Respect
q22.prompt: Do you feel consistently respected in tone, effort, honesty, and boundaries?
examples: Yes. One thing that feels respectful: They honor my boundaries the first time. One thing that doesn't: Nothing consistent stands out.
Mostly. One thing that feels respectful: They speak kindly even when upset. One thing that doesn't: They sometimes minimize my needs or rush me when I need time.
Mixed. One thing that feels respectful: They try. One thing that doesn't: They get sarcastic, dismissive, or inconsistent with honesty, and it undermines trust.

q23.title: Emotional Regulation Effect
q23.prompt: Overall, this relationship tends to make your nervous system feel:
examples: More regulated and grounded (e.g., my baseline anxiety drops with them. I feel more like myself and less reactive).
More open and hopeful (e.g., I feel energized about building, like my life expands with them, not contracts).
More anxious/activated (e.g., I overthink texts, feel uncertainty in my body, or feel like I am always calibrating to their moods).
More shut down/numb (e.g., I am present physically but emotionally muted. I avoid bringing up needs because it feels pointless).

q24.title: Conflict Pattern
q24.prompt: When tension shows up, which pattern is most true right now?

options.label: not enough conflict yet to know

examples: We talk and repair (e.g., we address issues directly, stay respectful, and actually resolve them instead of stacking resentment).
We avoid it (e.g., we change the subject, smooth it over, or pretend it is fine, but it shows up later as distance).
One of us shuts down (e.g., one person goes quiet, disappears, or becomes unavailable, so repair gets delayed or never happens).
It escalates then cools off (e.g., the issue becomes a blowup, then we reset without real repair, which trains the cycle).

q25.title: Repair Reliability
q25.prompt: After a hard moment, you usually feel:
examples: More connected (e.g., we owned our parts, understood each other better, and the repair increased trust).
About the same (e.g., the issue ended, but nothing deep changed. It is neutral, not building or breaking trust).
A little less safe (e.g., the repair was partial, so I feel hesitant to bring up similar needs again).
More distant (e.g., we never fully repaired, so I pull back, feel guarded, or question the relationship).

q26.title: Hard Topics Avoidance
q26.prompt: Is there anything you're avoiding because it might change the relationship? You don't need to share details, just the category.
examples: None. notes: Hard talks are uncomfortable, but we do them. I do not feel like I am hiding a landmine.
Money + timeline/commitment. notes: I have not asked about debt, spending, or what commitment timeline they actually want, and it affects my ability to say yes cleanly.
Sex/physical boundaries + exes. notes: There are assumptions about physical pace and about ex contact that could create betrayal if we do not name them.
Emotional needs + mental health. notes: I am avoiding naming a need because I fear it will change how they see me, which is already information.

q27.title: Not-Okay Conflict Behaviors (and what to do)
q27.prompt: Which conflict behaviors are not okay for you, and what should happen if one occurs?

fields.label: If one happens, what should the immediate response be?

examples: Yelling + insults/name-calling + breaking objects/intimidation. If one happens, what should the immediate response be?: I end the conversation immediately, leave the space if needed, and we only reconnect when calm. Repeated incidents mean I step back from the relationship.

Stonewalling + contempt/sarcasm. If one happens, what should the immediate response be?: We pause, set a specific time to resume (same day if possible), and the person who shuts down still communicates: I need 30 minutes, I will come back.

Jealousy control + privacy violations. If one happens, what should the immediate response be?: We name it as a boundary violation, clarify expectations, and if it repeats, I treat it as a dealbreaker because it predicts control.

q28.title: Values Alignment (Real-Life, Not Theory)
q28.prompt: Do your core values feel aligned in real life right now?
examples: Aligned. 1-2 values that feel aligned: honesty and family. 1-2 values that feel uncertain: none right now. notes: Our values show up in day-to-day choices, not just words.

Mostly aligned. 1-2 values that feel aligned: faith/spirituality and service. 1-2 values that feel uncertain: money and lifestyle pace. notes: We want the same big things, but the operating style may clash.

Mixed. 1-2 values that feel aligned: loyalty and growth. 1-2 values that feel uncertain: sexual boundaries or integrity. notes: The mismatch is showing up as recurring tension, not just hypothetical disagreement.

q29.title: The Hope It Changes Check
q29.prompt: Are you hoping something important will change if you commit?
examples: No (e.g., I can say yes to who they are today, not to a future version. Any growth would be a bonus, not a requirement).
Yes (e.g., I am hoping commitment will fix something like communication, effort, cleanliness, or emotional availability, which means I am not fully okay with the current reality).
Unsure (e.g., I am telling myself it will get better, but I cannot tell if that is faith in growth or denial of a pattern).

q30.title: What You Hope Would Change
q30.prompt: If yes or unsure: what are you hoping will change? (1-3 sentences)
examples: I hope they will become more consistent with communication and follow-through. Right now it feels like I am doing more of the emotional and logistical work.
I hope they will handle conflict with more ownership instead of defensiveness or withdrawal. I do not want a relationship where repair is rare.
I hope they will clarify ex boundaries and stop leaving gray areas that make me feel unstable. I need transparency, not control.
I hope I will stop feeling like I have to earn their effort. If I need to chase, I do not want to label it.

q31.title: Self-Editing Check
examples: More myself (e.g., I can be honest, tired, awkward, or intense and still feel liked. I do not fear punishment for authenticity).
Mostly myself (e.g., I am real, but I still hold back a couple topics or traits until trust is deeper).
Somewhat edited (e.g., I am tracking their reactions and adjusting myself to avoid disapproval. It is not extreme, but it is not free either).
Heavily edited (e.g., I feel like I am curating a version of me. If I relaxed, I think the relationship would wobble).

q32.title: The Quiet Dealbreaker
q32.prompt: Is there a potential dealbreaker you're trying not to look at yet? You don't have to name details.
examples: No; Category: prefer not to say; Notes: Nothing stands out as a dealbreaker. I am not avoiding anything major right now.
Yes; Category: life direction; Notes: Their lifestyle vision and mine may be incompatible, and I have been postponing the conversation because the chemistry is strong.
Unsure; Category: emotional availability; Notes: I do not know if they can show up consistently under stress, and I am afraid to test it because the answer could change everything.

q33.title: What's Driving DTR Urgency
q33.prompt: Which is most true right now?
examples: Grounded desire (e.g., I want to build with them because our values and patterns look healthy, and I feel calm about the direction).
Anxiety and need for certainty (e.g., the urgency spikes when I feel insecure, triggered, or afraid of replacement, not when I feel steady).
Both (e.g., I want them and I also want relief from uncertainty. I need to separate commitment from panic before I decide).
Neither (e.g., I do not feel pulled toward labeling. I may be coasting, avoiding a decision, or noticing a lack of fit).

q34.title: Your Body's Answer
q34.prompt: When you imagine being officially committed to them, your body feels:
examples: Calm/settled. In one sentence, why?: It feels like relief and stability, like I can exhale and be myself.
Excited/energized. In one sentence, why?: I feel motivated and hopeful, like building a future with them makes sense.
Tight/uneasy. In one sentence, why?: My body flags risk, like I am about to sign up for stress, pressure, or loss of self.
Mixed. In one sentence, why?: Part of me is drawn in, part of me braces. The ambivalence is the signal I need to explore.

q35.title: If They Wanted to Wait
q35.prompt: If they said not yet, you would mostly feel:
examples: Understanding (e.g., I can handle not yet if there is clear care and a plan for what we are learning next).
Hurt (e.g., it would feel like rejection, especially if they cannot articulate what needs to change or what timeline they want).
Anxious (e.g., I would start scanning for replacement or loss, and I would need clarity to stay regulated).
Relief (e.g., I want the connection, but I also feel pressure. Waiting would give me space to decide cleanly).

q36.title: Lean Today
q36.prompt: If you had to choose today, you would most want to:

options.label: move toward defining it, but not yet
keep it undefined for a while

examples: Define the relationship now (e.g., I have enough data, the risks are known, and I feel peace. I am ready to make agreements and move forward).
Move toward defining it, but not yet (e.g., I want exclusivity or clearer expectations first, then label when consistency is proven).
Keep it undefined for a while (e.g., I enjoy them, but I do not want pressure. I need more time observing patterns before adding stakes).
Step back or end it (e.g., my body or values are saying no, and continuing would be denial or attachment, not wisdom).

q37.title: Readiness Score (Now)
q37.prompt: On a scale of 1-10, how ready are you to define the relationship?

fields.label: Readiness score (1 = not ready at all, 10 = ready and at peace)
What would raise it by 1-2 points?

examples: 9. why that number?: We are basically acting committed and our conflict is respectful. what would raise it by 1-2 points?: Clarify exclusivity boundaries and make a simple plan for communication consistency.

6. why that number?: I like them, but I do not trust the pattern yet under stress. what would raise it by 1-2 points?: Watch follow-through for a few more weeks and have the hard conversation about direction.
3. why that number?: My nervous system is activated and I am minimizing concerns. what would raise it by 1-2 points?: Either we repair the core issue consistently, or I step back and stop forcing it.
10. why that number?: I feel calm, clear, and excited, and my yes is not a rescue or a panic. what would raise it by 1-2 points?: Nothing, I am already there.

q38.title: What You Still Need
q38.prompt: What do you still need to decide cleanly? Select any.
examples: Behavioral consistency + repair and conflict stability. notes: I need to see how we handle stress and repair, not just how good it feels when things are easy.
A hard conversation + clarity about exclusivity. notes: We are close, but the agreement layer is missing. Until we define the rules, I cannot say yes cleanly.
Meet friends/family + time availability clarity. notes: I need to see integration and whether our real-life schedules are compatible long-term.
Emotional safety + faith/spiritual alignment. notes: I can date without full alignment, but I cannot define without it if faith is central for me.

q39.title: Healthy Yes Requirements
q39.prompt: For a healthy yes, what must be true? (Up to 3 bullet points)
examples: Behavioral consistency + repair and conflict stability. notes: I need to see how we handle stress and repair, not just how good it feels when things are easy.
A hard conversation + clarity about exclusivity. notes: We are close, but the agreement layer is missing. Until we define the rules, I cannot say yes cleanly.
Meet friends/family + time availability clarity. notes: I need to see integration and whether our real-life schedules are compatible long-term.
Emotional safety + faith/spiritual alignment. notes: I can date without full alignment, but I cannot define without it if faith is central for me.

q40.title: Healthy No / Not Yet Next Step
q40.prompt: If the answer is no or not yet, what would the most respectful next step look like for you?
examples: Not yet: I would name the specific missing data (exclusivity clarity, conflict pattern, direction) and agree on a time-box to re-evaluate, like 2 to 4 weeks, with one or two concrete conversations planned.
No: I would be honest and kind, stop escalating intimacy, and create clean space so we do not drift into ambiguity or emotional dependence.
Not yet: I would slow the pace, reduce pressure, and gather data intentionally rather than staying in limbo. If there is no progress, I would step back.
No: I would end it respectfully, with clarity and minimal mixed signals, so both of us can heal and move forward without confusion.

q41.title: The Honesty Check
q41.prompt: Is there a part of you that already knows your answer but is afraid to admit it?
examples: No. If yes/unsure: (blank). notes: I feel clear and I am not hiding from the answer.
Yes. If yes/unsure: I know I do not want to define this, but I am attached to the comfort and attention. notes: I am scared of loneliness or regret.
Unsure. If yes/unsure: Part of me knows, but I keep arguing with myself. notes: I need to face the data instead of the fantasy.

q42.title: Faith Relevance
q42.prompt: How relevant is faith/spiritual life to your relationship decisions?
examples: Central (e.g., faith shapes standards, pacing, and long-term direction, so misalignment here is a real dealbreaker, not a footnote).
Important (e.g., it matters for lifestyle and integrity, but I can navigate some differences if there is respect and shared direction).
Somewhat relevant (e.g., I value spirituality or meaning, but it is not the main filter for defining the relationship).
Not relevant (e.g., faith is not a factor in my decisions, so alignment here would not drive a yes or no).

q43.title: Spiritual Integrity
q43.prompt: If faith matters to you: does this relationship support or strain your spiritual integrity right now?
examples: Supports. in what way?: The relationship reinforces my values and standards. I feel more honest, more disciplined, and more aligned with what I believe.
Strains. in what way?: I feel pulled to compromise standards or hide parts of the relationship. It creates guilt, secrecy, or a sense of double life.
Mixed. in what way?: Some parts support my faith, but there are recurring situations that strain integrity, like boundaries, Sabbath approach, or value conflicts.

q44.title: Faith-Based Expectations / Standards
q44.prompt: If applicable, which faith-based expectations matter for defining the relationship? Select any.
examples: Shared worship/church life + Sabbath day approach. notes: I want shared participation and a compatible Sunday rhythm so faith is not a constant friction point.
Sexual standards/boundaries (e.g., chastity expectations) + temple/covenant direction (if applicable). notes: Defining the relationship requires clear agreements so we do not rely on willpower alone.
Word of wisdom style alignment (substances) + tithing/generosity and stewardship approach. notes: Lifestyle and stewardship choices affect long-term trust and partnership.
Family integration expectations + roles/leadership expectations. notes: I want clarity on how faith shapes family life, decision-making, and expectations, not vague assumptions.

q45.title: Guidance Style Preference
q45.prompt: When receiving guidance (human or AI), you prefer it to be:
examples: Gentle and validating (e.g., I can hear truth best when it is compassionate and non-shaming, especially if I feel tender or triggered).
Direct and honest (e.g., I want the clean answer and the hard truth quickly, even if it stings).
Structured and practical (e.g., give me a checklist, a decision tree, or steps I can take, not just reflections).
Reflective and exploratory (e.g., ask sharp questions that help me see myself and the pattern, then let me decide).

q46.title: Challenge vs Comfort Dial
q46.prompt: Right now, do you want to be challenged, comforted, or both?
examples: Mostly challenged (e.g., point out my blind spots, call out avoidance, and help me make a clean decision instead of staying in limbo).
Mostly comforted (e.g., help me regulate and feel safe first so I can think clearly, then we can look at the hard stuff).
Both (e.g., start with emotional grounding, then move into direct truth and next steps. I want care and accountability).
Not sure (e.g., I do not know what I need yet, so start with questions and let my response guide the dial).

q47.title: What You Most Want Help With
q47.prompt: What do you most want help seeing clearly right now?
examples: My feelings + my readiness. notes: I want to separate love from anxiety and see whether my yes is calm or compulsive.
Their signals + having the conversation. notes: I need help turning mixed signals into clear questions and a respectful DTR conversation.
Expectations and boundaries + conflict/repair. notes: I want to define what I actually need and whether this relationship can meet it consistently.
Values/faith alignment + making the decision. notes: I want help weighing compatibility versus attachment so I do not choose chemistry over long-term fit.

q48.title: Privacy Preference for Outputs
q48.prompt: How private do you want your results and recommendations to be?
examples: Just for me (e.g., I want private clarity first so I can think without social pressure or negotiation).
Shareable summary (e.g., I want a clean, non-blaming summary I can share to start a good conversation).
Shareable full output (e.g., I want the full detail so we can work through it together and not oversimplify the issues).
Not sure yet (e.g., default to private, then I can choose to share later once I see what it says).

lite.title: Lite Check-in
lite.post_timebox_activity: Take a break and do something enjoyable.
